titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records CBHM.0031
titlestmt.author: Alice Griffin

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-09-18 13:40:27 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.unittitle: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records

physdesc.extent: in 9 manuscript boxes, one half manuscript box, one shoebox, and one oversize box.

did.abstract: The Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records consists of physical organizational files and newsletters, and digital surrogates primarily of photographs but also including event programs, tickets, brochures and obituaries from 1905 to 2019.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records consists of physical organizational files and newsletters and digital surrogates primarily of photographs but also including event programs, tickets, brochures and obituaries. The organizational files include minutes from Gamma Iota Lambda chapter board meetings; committee reports; national, regional, and chapter correspondence; event invitations; and press releases. The newsletters include Gamma Iota Lamba chapter newsletters and national Alpha Phi Alpha newsletters. Series 3: Photographs, 1905-2010, consists of digital surrogates of photographs depicting fraternity gatherings, awards ceremonies, anniversaries, and meetings on Long Island, in Brooklyn, and other locations.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., the first intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity established for African American men, was founded on December 4, 1906 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York by seven college men who recognized the need for a strong bond of brotherhood among African descendants in the United States. The fraternity initially served as a study and support group for students who faced racial prejudice, both educationally and socially, at Cornell.

The founders, known to their brethren as the 'seven jewels,' along with early leaders of the fraternity, laid a firm foundation for Alpha Phi Alpha's principles of scholarship, fellowship, good character, and the uplifting of humanity. The organization has been interracial since 1945.

Alpha Phi Alpha chapters were established at other colleges and universities, many of them historically Black institutions, soon after the founding at Cornell. The first alumni chapter was established in 1911. The Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter was chartered in Brooklyn in 1945 with the aim of advancing the well-being of Black Brooklynites and established programs to promote education, health and justice in their neighborhoods. Among the membership are attorneys, civic leaders, architects, clergy, educators, physicians, and veterans. Prominent members include Dr. Hobart S. Jarrett (1915-2005), Alton Burton (1925-2018), and Myles A. Paige (1898-1983).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Jessy Dwyer and Andre McKenzie on behalf of the Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, 2024.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into four series:

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The originals of digitized materials have been retained by the donor.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The digitized material in this collection is available on our digital collections portal under the call number prefix ALPH.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma Iota Lambda chapter records, CBHM.0031; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The digital files were created and cataloged by Special Collections Cataloger, Deborah Tint, and the finding aid was written by Archivist, Alice Griffin.
News clippings were photocopied onto archival paper and originals discarded. Folder titles in brackets were provided by the archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright retained by the owner. Please consult library staff for further details and assistance.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Two files in Series 1: Organizational files are restricted indefinitely because of personally identifiable information. These restrictions are noted on the file level.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: After the relevant articles were photocopied, the full issues of Afro Times and Our Time Press were moved to the Brooklyn Historical Society newspaper collection (ARC.258).

African American fraternal organizations

controlaccess.corpname: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity. Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter (Brooklyn, N.Y.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is in original order, arranged chronologically with special subject files spanning a long period of time at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1: Organizational files, 1944-2019, includes news clippings, meeting minutes, committee reports, correspondence, orientation books for officers, press releases, scholarship applications, and event invitations related to chapter, regional, and national fraternity business. Correspondence includes thank you notes from members receiving sympathy or get well gifts. Folders titled "Initiation info" are mostly invitations to member initiation events, but also include forms filled out by prospective applicants. Of note in the 1956 correspondence folder is a letter thanking the chapter for their contribution to the Montgomery Improvement Association signed by Martin Luther King, Jr.
A file on the history of Alpha wives, a biographical file of member and World Trade Center engineer Alton Burton, and a file on general chapter history are at the end of the series.
Most of the material from the 1940s are photocopies.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Two files in this series are restricted indefinitely because of personally identifiable information. These restrictions are noted on the file level.

did.unittitle: Gamma Iota Lambda Chapter Senior Brothers' Luncheon award to Bro. Lawrence D. Bannister

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This award is a glass obelisk manufactured by Crown Awards etched with the Alpha Phi Alpha crest and the lettering: "Bro. Lawrence D. Bannister / Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc. / G.I.L. Chapter Senior Brothers' Luncheon / May 26, 2012"

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is in original, chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 2: Constitutions and by-laws, 1946-circa 2000, is made up of booklets containing the constitution and by-laws of the Gamma Iota Lambda chapter of Alpha Phi Alpha. There is also one booklet with the constitution and by-laws of the New York Association of Chapters of Alpha. Some of the documents were sent out to chapter officers for comments and revisions.

did.unittitle: [Constitution and by-laws for the New York Association of Chapters of Alpha]

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by newsletter and then in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3: Newsletters, 1955-2012, includes newsletters published at the national, regional, and chapter levels of Alpha Phi Alpha. Newsletters include the Alpha newsletter, published by the Office of the General Secretary; The Alpha Spirit, official newsletter of the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity; Alpha newsletter, published by the Office of the Executive Director; the Chapter Bulletin: The Newsletter for the Chapters of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity; The Fraternal Spirit, published by the New York Association of Chapters of Alpha; and the Gamma Iota Lambda newsletter.

did.unittitle: [New York Association of Chapters of Alpha Official Newsletter]

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The original has been retained by the donor.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This file is available on our digital collections portal under the call number ALPH_0283.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3: Photographs, 1905-2010, consists of digital surrogates of photographs depicting fraternity gatherings, awards ceremonies, anniversaries, and meetings on Long Island, in Brooklyn, and other locations. The photographs also depict the gatherings of the Alpha Wives of Brooklyn and Long Island, which raised funds for scholarships.

Some of the photographs were housed in an album with captions written under the items. In most cases these captions were written by member John R. Rice, Jr. Other photographs had inscriptions on the reverse, or had separate caption documents. All of this information has been added to the item record on CBH's digital collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files have been assigned call numbers in numerical order in the order in which they were scanned from the donor's files. ALPH_0001 through ALPH_0184 are stored in a photo album and the rest of the materials are stored in two folders.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals
originalsloc.p: The originals have been retained by the donor.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: These files are available on our digital collections portal under the call number prefix ALPH.
